授業目的: Students can get a clear image of the revolutionary change in the world order by analyzing international political issues, with which Japan is confronting in today's multipolar world. This course will examine issues and agenda of the current Japanese foreign policy and discuss those issues with students. This will be useful to the students who wish to become diplomat or member of the international organizations as well as political and business leader.
到達目標: Students will get a clear understanding on what are the key issues of the foreign policy of Japan both in theory and practice, thus enabling them to discuss various issues of Japanese and world politics on a level comparable to that of the business and professional people.
特記事項: 本授業科目は、“オンライン授業60単位制限対象科目”ではありません。 The course is not subject to the 60-credit limit for online courses.

Oct. 6 "Japanese Foreign Policy and the National Interest"

In this class we will be discussing the basic policy of Japanese diplomacy to cope with the most pressing issues with its neighbors, including how to cope with expanding China and destabilizing North Korea (DPRK) as well as how to manage good relations with difficult neighbor of South Korea (ROK). Japan has territorial issues with all its neighboring countries including Russia.

第6回:
Oc. 27 "History and Diplomacy (2): Can Japan reconcile with its neighbors?" A comparison to Germany's case of overcoming history issue. Germany has always been equated as a model country for Japan in overcoming the history issue. Germany for most of its part reconciled with the victim countries. Why was it possible? What kind of reconciliation measures were taken by Germany? What are the reactions coming from the victim countries? Apology and forgiveness are the crucial elements for a successful reconciliation process. We would like to discuss key factors leading to reconciliation by comparing Germany and Japan. We would know the different reason and background for the two countries and simply juxtaposing these two countries may not be a relevant approach. PowerPoint materials will be made available for this class.

第7回:
Nov.3 "Thinking of Japan's Security: The Japanese Constitution and the right to collective self-defense."

In this class we would like to examine how Japan has been trying to overcome its constitutional constraints, particularly the use of the right to collective self-defense in case of eminent existential threat to its security.
Since the end of the Cold War in 1989, Japan embarked on a new stage to proactively contribute to the maintenance of international peace and security through military and non-military means at its disposal. However, there are constitutional constraints, when Japan dispatches self-defense forces beyond its territory for the purpose of UN Peace Operations including UN-PKO and other military activities to maintain peace. In Japan, the issue of the right to collective self-defense has always been argued in connection with the dispatch of the Self-Defense Forces outside Japan. Whether Japan has overcome this issue, though not completely but to a certain degree? This politically sensitive but critical issue will be examined and discussed.

第8回:
Nov.10 "Geopolitical Importance of Europe to Japan: The possibilities and Limitations of EU (Brexit/Euro/Migration/Refugee/ COVID-19 Pandemic, Ukrainian War etc.)."
With the Brexit and the rising populism in many countries of EU, massive migration flow to EU countries and the widening gap among European countries over the reaction to Ukrainian War, EU could, in worst situation, be opting for disintegration. Together with the weakening of the liberal world order the voices over "Decline of the West" could be heard. What will be the influence of this geopolitical trend in Europe to Japan? We will be examining possible negative impact of this and thinking how this trend could be reversed. The role of Japan and the EU/European countries to cope with the division of the world or decoupling of the US and China, will also be discussed.

第9回:
Nov.17 "The United Nations at crossroad: its 78 years history and the possibilities and limitations of the UN"
The UN has not been functioning well for a long time as the UN Charter envisages. This being the case because of the Cold War in the past and due to the self-centered behavior of the 5 Permanent Members(P5) of the UN Security Council for many years. Taking examples of Ukraine, Syria, Iran and the disarmament issues, particularly nuclear disarmament, the Security Council has not been a main actor when strategic interests of the P5 and 5 Nuclear Weapon countries are at stake. This has also been the case in such field of non- military nature as climate change (Paris Agreement) or Pandemic of Coronavirus. We have, however a challenging UN initiative like SDGs. In this class we will be examining why the UN and multilateralism are not functioning well particularly in the maintenance of international peace and security and discussing what must be done.

第10回:
Nov.24 "The reform of the Security Council and the UN diplomacy of Japan: Can UN be changed?"
The key to the UN's role as a collective security system to maintain international peace and security is in the hand of the Security Council and its five permanent members(P5). However, the Security Council could not always comply with this request and the reform was called for over the years. After the demise of the Cold War, Japan embarked on the reform course and started a new campaign in 1992. Japan, Germany, Brazil, and India created a Draft Resolution (G4 Resolution) for the reform of the Security Council in 2005. However, after hectic negotiations in the General Assembly, G4 was obliged to abandon to put this draft resolution for voting. Since then, the negotiations have been conducted every year in the GA, but it is going nowhere. What are the key issues and why the negotiations stagnate? We will be examining this complicated political issue and discussing how the member countries are able to cut the Gordian's Knot.
